awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Gel Permeation Chromatograph with Multiple Detectors to Expand Capabilities for Macromolecular Characterization
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Instrumentation Programs. Professor Madalyn Radlauer from San Jose State University and colleagues Melanie McNeil, Chester Simocko and Eric Tillman are acquiring a gel permeation chromatograph (GPC) equipped with refractive index, ultrviolet and multiangle light scattering detectors. In general, gel permeation chromatography is used to separate compounds based on molecular weight, size, and shape.   The technique is commonly employed for the analysis or purification of polymers. The award support collaborations in polymer science between San Jose State University and Santa Clara University which promote research experiences for their large and diverse undergraduate student bodies. Summer research students are recruited from nearby community colleges thus expanding research training. The instrument gives students experience using vital instrumentation that they carry with them into their careers.

The award provides gel permeation chromatograph instrumentation useful for examining polymers used as catalyst scaffolds as well as for studies of precision polymers used for ion transport and energy storage. The GPC is employed in evaluating the effect of additives on the morphology and performance of polysulfone water purification membranes and for studying post-polymerization reactions leading to topological architectures such as cyclic polymers, star polymers, and branched polymers. The instrument is helpful for investigations of redox-active polymers used in organic batteries and other charge storage devices. Other uses of the GPC are for determining structure-property relationships of recycled polymers and composites. Finally, the instrument is used for studies of the effects of irradiation-based sterilization techniques on the properties of polymers used in implantable devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: SAN JOSE STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION

por.por_cntn:
This project enabled the purchase of a TOSOH EcoSEC Elite gel permeation chromatograph (GPC) with refractive index, ultraviolet, and multi-angle light scattering detectors, which was installed at San Jose State University (SJSU) in December 2019. This instrument allows us to separate and characterize molecules based on their size (mass) and the distribution of sizes present in a sample. Gel permeation chromatography is especially useful for macromolecules (also known as polymers) - long chain-like molecules made up of repeating subunits - because controlling size is one of the challenges in making polymers. In addition, the multiple types of detectors present in this instrument allow for more accurate characterization of polymer size when the molecules have 3D structure on the nanoscale because the separation method depends on the radius of the molecule as it goes through the system rather than the mass. The light scattering detector allows for absolute mass determination, even for structured polymers such as star polymers, cyclic polymers, and polymeric nanoparticles. This is also a significant benefit for when you cannot purchase a standard of known size for a polymer with a specific chemical formula, e.g. when you are making a brand new material; the absolute mass determination allows you to get accurate data without having to compare directly with a standard.

The installation of this GPC at SJSU was a considerable enhancement of our analytical capabilities for polymers and inspired the collection of all instruments for polymer characterization into the SJSU FAMILab (Fabrication and Analysis of Macromolecules Instrumentation Laboratory). This shared instrument facility aims to enhance collaboration between researchers studying macromolecules at SJSU and neighboring institutions, including Santa Clara University (SCU, the home institution of one of the co-PIs on this project). A number of research projects at SJSU and SCU have benefitted from the use of this instrument including projects making new types of polymers and studying polymers with different 3D structures. One significant impact of the project has been the training of a diverse group of SJSU and SCU undergraduate and Master's students on the use of this instrument and data analysis and interpretation. This instrument also adds the opportunity for new experiments in undergraduate and Master's level courses at SJSU and SCU so that a larger group of students can benefit from the introduction to this modern specialized equipment.


Last Modified: 12/20/2022
Modified by: Madalyn R Radlauer

Image
  • TOSOH EcoSEC Elite gel permeation chromatograph installed at San Jose State University
    Madalyn Radlauer
    Public Domain

    gel permeation chromatograph
